qas.question: When did the term "Near and Middle East" hold stage?

answers.text: a few years before World War I

qas.question: What proved to be less acceptable to a colonial point of view?
When did Captain T.C. Fowle write of a trip he had taken from Karachi to Syria?
In the book Fowle wrote, what is the entire region considered?

context: <a1_0>The term "Near and Middle East,"<a1_0/> held the stage for <a0_0>a few years before World War I<a0_0/>. It proved to be less acceptable to a colonial point of view that saw the entire region as one. In <a2_0>1916<a2_0/> Captain T.C. Fowle, 40th Pathans <a3_0>(troops of British India<a3_0/>), wrote of a trip he had taken from Karachi to Syria just before the war. The book does not contain a single instance of "Near East." Instead, the entire region is considered <a4_0>"the Middle East.<a4_0/>" The formerly Near Eastern sections of his trip are now "Turkish" and not Ottoman.
